poem:
"Upon the Aged Tides of Mary Poppins"

Brushed in hues of faded gold,
the nanny of sharp tongue and satchel
ascends.
Once a U, now archived a PG,
bounced upon a trampling board 
of shifting canonical norms.
Discriminatory language, the papers quote,
gathers dust in the umbrella's dance,
both victim and victor of an ebony waltz,
across a changing cultural landscape.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Mary Poppins’ UK age rating raised to PG due to discriminatory language Mary Poppins has had its age rating lifted to a PG by the British Board of Film Classification (BBFC) almost 60 years after it was first released. The film’s rating has been upgraded from U – which signifies no material likely to offend or harm – to one advising parental guidance due to the use of discriminatory language, the Daily Mail reported. It". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
